awd_titl_txt: Multi-Scale Dynamics Studies Using the Drake Antarctic Agile Meteor Radar
awd_abstract_narration:
The Earth's layered atmosphere extends from the surface to the altitudes of about 100 km, consisting of the most lower layer - troposphere, and then extending up through the mesosphere and lower thermosphere, which includes a layer of strongly ionizes air called ionosphere (MLTI). Due to atmospheric perturbations caused by the underlying Earth's landscape of ocean, land, and mountains, the gravity (or internal) waves (GW) are generated with quasi-periodic oscillations most familiar as the wave-like cloud patterns. This project seeks to experimentally investigate the role of atmospheric gravity waves while they propagate up and at distance through the mesosphere to thermosphere, and affect in some way the ionosphere. A well-known major 'hotspot' of gravity waves activity exists over the South America?s Andes, Antarctic Peninsula, and Drake Passage located between these landmasses and connecting the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. This hotspot is fed by major GW sources in this region that include high mountains, strong jet streams, and the passage of vigorous frontal weather systems. 

The award will reinstate the Drake Antarctic Agile MEteor Radar (DrAAMER) that was deployed at the Brazilian Antarctic Station Comandante Ferraz in 2010. Upon reinstatement, the radar will be employed in diverse observations along with another meteor radar, SAAMER, deployed in Southern Argentina. These observations will be used for studies of the coupling and dynamics of atmospheric waves generated at lower altitudes over the Drake Passage and then propagating into the mesosphere, lower thermosphere, and ionosphere regions. This research addresses topics that are of high interest and relevance to diverse scientific communities, especially for defining more accurate parameterizations of the MLTI dynamics for the weather prediction and climate modeling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project employed a radar measuring winds at very high altitudes, ~80-100 km (~50-60 miles), from a remote Brazilian research base on King George Island at ~62 degrees south near the tip of the Antarctic Peninsula. Its purpose was to help us understand the atmospheric circulation and variability at very high altitudes. The motions at these altitudes vary from small-scale turbulence to very large planetary-scale motions that are large versions of the tides in the oceans and the low- and high-pressure systems that drive our daily weather in the troposphere. These motions are diagnosed using roughly 30 such radars that extend from the Antarctic to high northern latitudes. 

This type of radar is called a meteor radar because it estimates winds from reflections of radar pulses from meteor trails created as the meteors ablate in the atmosphere, which leave trails of ionization that move toward or away from the radar due to the large-scale winds. These are the same meteors we can often see in the various meteor showers, but the radars are much more sensitive than our eyes, and very small meteors are always present.  

Surprisingly, perhaps, measurements at these high altitudes can provide valuable additional guidance for weather prediction at Earth?s surface because measurements of large-scale planetary waves and tides extending to high altitudes in the atmosphere enable better predictions of their evolutions and influences than would be possible without these measurements. Such measurements are not yet incorporated in data used by weather prediction agencies, but this will soon change as new measurements of winds and temperatures from space become available.        

These radar data have been used to constrain model wind fields that allow us to explore the responses at higher altitudes to smaller-scale atmospheric waves that are generated by airflow over mountains or deep convection over the U.S. Midwest and elsewhere. Such modeling will be used in another research program funded by the National Science Foundation that will occur in June 2023 over the Midwest named the Convective Gravity Waves (CGWaveS) experiment. This experiment will employ extensive ground-based instruments and a Gulfstream V research aircraft that will measure turbulence at flight altitudes and the CGWs with on-board lasers making measurements above the aircraft and extending to ~100 km (~60 mile) altitudes.
